course.subject: MGMT
course.name: Negotiation
course.description: Theories and processes of negotiation; negotiation strategies; contextual factors in negotiation; other issues in negotiation.

reviews.comment_content: Content of course is quite interesting. You have take-home cases which are pretty simple and one lesson every week would be negotiation practices. Those practices are straightforward and mostly for attendance only.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall teaching is very good and the professor makes lectures very interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is out worse than expected and there is not explicit guidelines for you to gain marks. There is no way you can know why you get such a grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very light compared to other courses. Though there are quizzes almost every lesson, they are very straightforward and simple.

reviews.author: Seonghun
reviews.title: Negotiation
reviews.comment_content: In two classes each week, one class is used for negotiation and the other class is used for negotiation debrief. During the negotiation, the professor will walk into the room and see how the negotiation is going on. There are 2 essays to write. The first one asks you to write about a personal negotiation that you have done in real life. The second one asks you to write about any kind of real negotiation that happened in the world.
reviews.comment_teaching: Stephen is a fun professor who will prevent you from falling asleep. He encourages students to speak up and guide the lesson through the slides. Debriefing negotiation cases were extremely interesting because students were able to understand the opponents' circumstances. Overall very entertaining class.
reviews.comment_grading: IF you are an outgoing person who aren't shy to speak up and enjoy participating in class, you are the right person that suits this class. If you aren't, you should probably not take this course. I honestly didn't speak that much in this course. If you can speak up a lot, and the professor knows your name, you can get a high grade. Considering it was 25% for attendance (like actual participating in class, not just attending), I should have spoken more.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that bad considering it as a 4 credit course. You won't have much to do in the first two weeks, but as time goes, you have to prepare for the negotiation cases. The passages get longer and more complex, so you will need more time to understand the whole passage. You would also need time for how to strategically target the opponent in a negotiation. However, the overall workload isn't that much. Pure participation in the course is more important, and this can be done without that much preparation. There are some quizzes for some negotiation cases which ask for very easy concepts. (it's never stressful)

reviews.author: Hosea
reviews.comment_content: Each week starts with a simulated negotiation. Students are grouped randomly, so they will face a different opponent (usually a complete stranger) every time. It is the best time to apply what you have learned from the class, or to get really frustrated in the negotiation and be prepared to learn something new in the debrief session following the negotiation class. The negotiation techniques taught are somewhat common sense, but can come in handy when you are consciously using them against those who are not aware of how powerful these tools can be.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Stephen Nason is nice (if he is not making fun of you) and humorous. He explains the concepts clearly, and he has ways to make sure most people know what is going on. Students can hardly fall asleep in his class.
reviews.comment_grading: Attendance and exams are crucial. Punctuality is also important because the in-class short quizzes are very short - you will miss it if you are late. The exams are quite straight forward if you have learned the material and are able to use it in the practical part. Grade cut-offs are not obvious, but it is not hard to do well in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: All you have to do is to be prepared and show up in the class (punctually) and exams (2 in total). The only take-home part is to prepare for the negotiation of the following week. A 2-question quiz will be administered to make sure you are well prepared - but that's nothing. You can hardly believe it is a 4-credit course with such a minimal workload.

reviews.author: Chan Lok Yiu
reviews.comment_content: The course is very useful. You will learn the technique of negotiation by negotiating under a topic each week. They are all based on real life cases. Then, we will review the negotiation process and learn how to do it better.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Professor is really great. He is funny and he shared a lot of experiences of his own. He is really enthusiastic and makes the class very lively.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading depends on attendance, quiz, mid-term, final exam.

Attendance will be recorded for each negotiation.

Quiz are easy. You just need to read the 1-2 pages background information for negotiation, then you will know the answer without memorizing anything.

Mid-term and final exam are based on MC, short-question based on cases.

There was bonus points for the people who got the highest points in the last negotiation.
reviews.comment_workload:
Little workload. You only need to read the background information before class, once per week.

For mid-term exam and final exam, you only need to study the powerpoints. The contents are not too much and they always duplicate. So it is easy to study for.

reviews.author: Carlo
reviews.title: Strongly reccomend
reviews.comment_content: Negotiation styles & techniques, strategies & issues in multiple first-hand practices.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture based, no textbook
Attendence is mandatory
Every week you practice a new negotiation in lecture with classmates.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendence
Essay
Midterm
Final

Strong curve.
There are short, easy pop-up quizzes eventually.
Final is cumulative but heavily concentrated on second part material.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quick reading of your role for the negotiation before each lecture.
Midterm and Final don't require much studying, yet application of class concepts. Hence it's important to attend lecture and keep up with strategies and issues.

reviews.author: Emin
reviews.title: Good teaching
reviews.comment_content: Very informative and useful I would say
reviews.comment_teaching: He has a good accent and easy to understand him. He likes to interact with the students.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is good but they will really care about your participation. you might think they are not checking whether you are attending the class but they actually are.
reviews.comment_workload: Not high. Class participation is very important. And you have to write two real-life negotiation papers as midterm and final assignment. and they are graded very generously. It is more about the content than the use of language, BE CREATIVE!!!!

reviews.author: SHANGchii
reviews.title: New Professor, Not Inspiring
reviews.comment_content: There will be lectures and negotiation practices to give students a taste of negotiation. However, the content was disorganized. Usually Tuesday session would be for negotiation, and Thursday session would be the evaluation session. Yet, what I found confusing was that most of the time the Thursday sessions were not evaluating the negotiation case we had just done; instead, the professor may spend half of the class discussing the negotiation case that had been done one or two weeks ago.
reviews.comment_teaching: This professor tried to appear to be funny but obviously he just had no clue on how to interact with his students. Therefore, it was often the case that half of the class was missing in the evaluation session on Thursday. I would say if you want to take this class, do not expect the professor would give you some really inspiring lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. One mid-term, one final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is appropriate for a 4-credit course. All you have to do is to read the case before going to each negotiation session.

reviews.author: lostsoul
reviews.title: Good choice if you are interested and able to join lectures
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers the fundamentals in handling negotiations. Negotiation practices will take place every 2 lessons (though you have to pay an extra fee for the cases but it worth). Usually after the practices, prof will review the case and explain how to perform better in the scenarios.

Several topics include: Distributive interest negotiation. contributive interest, trading of interests, conflicts, emotions management, cultural differences, coalition, etc.

It is allowed to miss one case practices without penalty, so it should be manageable as long as you are willing to commit to the course

Usually having a large amount of WBB or exchange students, can definitely tell the class atmosphere is different from other courses, people are lot more engaging and willing to share their ideas in class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very passionate and experienced, share quite some real life examples he had and is able to associate them back to the course content in illustrating how the negotiations skills can be executed

The TA is also responsible and able to support promptly to any logistics support etc.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance and participation in class discussions are important for the course (around 30%)

a couple of writing assignments on personal negotiation experiences and preparing a summary as a personal negotiation guide at the end of the course

Having both midterms and finals, but is not that difficult if catching up lecture content
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments are not require high amount of workload, only filling some researches and some short writings.

Do require active participation in lecture times though if that would be your concern

reviews.author: baebokchi
reviews.title: highly recommend
reviews.comment_content:
Really might help you in the future
From salary negotiation to various types of negotiations,
the contents are mostly useful.
There are weekly reading materials that you can use, which is good for having an insight of real life situations.
The in-class negotiation is quite good.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teachings are good
of course, as a native, his english is good to understand
And his classes are entertaining as well.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is quite harsh. Although I put lots of effort on the personal negotiation, the grade was not good enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is quite good.
Class quizes based on reading
Midterm
Finals
Personal negotiaiton guide
Individual negotiation essay

reviews.author: dp
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting class. Very in depth coverage of negotiation. Worth taking even if you are an experienced negotiator
reviews.comment_teaching: One of the easiest to listen to lecturers ive had
reviews.comment_grading: Getting an A is tricky as it is very competitive but in general the grading is fair. The exams are not too bad although the mean was around 50 percent for both in my group. Standard deviation around 10 percent.
reviews.comment_workload: Its fine. If you attend all classes and try your best in the negotiations you will only have to study a little bit to do well in the exams.

reviews.author: USTSPACE_
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting content. Every week, one section will be used for real-time negotiation exercises. Students will be randomly separated into pairs or teams to negotiate with their opponents. The complexity of the negotiation exercises will increase as the course progresses. Another section of the week will be used to debrief the negotiation exercises and add new content related to the negotiation exercises, such as the different genres of negotiation and negotiation skills.

It is worth mentioning that every student has to pay around HKD 300 for course materials, which would be collected after the add-drop period.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nason is one of the best professors I have encountered at HKUST. He is very passionate in his teaching and always tries his best to answer students' questions. Thus, there are a lot of exchange students
reviews.comment_grading:
Exam 1: 20%
Exam 2 (cumulative): 20%
Personal Negotiation: 15%
Negotiation Guide: 5%
Quiz for negotiation: 5%
Participation & discussion: 20%
Attendance (By negotiation form): 10%

Participation is very important. Try your best to raise your hands and let prof recognise you.

I got a c range in the class, with 60.5/100 in exam 1, 42/100 in exam 2, 19/25 in Personal Negotiation Paper. Other grades are unknown.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite a lot. You have to prepare for the negotiation exercise every week before the first section. Also, you have to be very familiar with the course content for the two exams.

reviews.author: Jasmine Chang
reviews.title: Best class
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting. Many international students. A diverse and interactive class. Different cases include salary negotiation, business negotiation and so on.
reviews.comment_teaching: story teller and interesting teacher. Definitely will enjoy his class. Even I have a 9 am class I still enjoy a lot and don't want to miss any of the negotiations!
reviews.comment_grading: Haven't knew it yet
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty low. Sometimes have to read a 8-15 pages cases before class. But overall I felt like the workload is acceptable and have a lot of takeaways. But normally average you only have to spend 1 and a half hour per week.

reviews.author: heloo;bhfbvieqb
reviews.title: Negotiations review
reviews.comment_content: super interesting and useful. really fun classes.  You learn a lot about different negotiations tactics which you can use a lot in future careers. he uses a lot of examples and creative stories which are super fun to listen to.
reviews.comment_teaching: super engaging. he asks the students a lot of questions and lets them interact and contribute a lot. he is very clear with a lot of structure and interesting content.
reviews.comment_grading:
seems fair. You have to participate and show up to class, if you do that you will end up with a satifatory grade. then you just have to study a little bot for exams. also there is a paper you have to writte, which seems fine because it is on a really fun topic and we have sooo much time to do it.

It's all fair and great.
reviews.comment_workload: not that much work, just show up to classes. on Tuesdays you do a negotiation with your classmates and then on thursday you discuss it with the class and professor. not a lot of reading, no homework really, all seems great.

reviews.author: byypan
reviews.comment_content: very interesting content. loved learning more about negotiation in the workplace. i am very excited to use this course knowledge in real-life situations. one of my top courses i took in my semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: effective teaching style. take time to speak/connect with your professor - it will be a great connectino to have.
reviews.comment_grading: fair grading, received adequate grades on all my assignments. just show up to lectures, participate, do the work necessary, and you will do well in the class.
reviews.comment_workload: a bit work heavy but able to balance with other courses.

reviews.author: Lydia_di
reviews.title: Short Review Summary
reviews.comment_content: Everything is simple to understand and it is very practical. There will be discussion almost every class and so it really helps to polish your negotiation skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy to understand and very helpful. The professor is very interactive.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Class Participation: 25%
2. Attendance: 15%
3. Negotiation Preparation: 5%
4. Research Participation: 5%
5. Midterm Actual Negotiation: 20%
6. Final Actual Negotiation: 30%
reviews.comment_workload: Very manageable. You need to read the case before class every time and use it to discuss after. There will be a short quiz or a one-page preparation paper before several negotiation exercises. There are also two ‘Actual Negotiation’ assignments due during the semester. For these assignments, you are required to go out and actually negotiate for something. You can negotiate for anything.

reviews.author: Jggjjkkj
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting content with a lot of in-class activities. Professor included a lot of interesting topics and tactics to teach us how to negotiate. About 2/3 of the time of the course would group with other classmates to negotiate on certain topics.

There would be evaluation section after the negotiation time to evaluate the class result and tactics used, so it would be very effective to know whether we have used the tactics correctly or not
reviews.comment_teaching: A lot of interaction and question time. Professor Nason is a very nice and funny person so class time it was very engaging. He also shares a lot of real-life example of how to deliver those tactics on real life situations, find it was a very good way to learn and absorb.
reviews.comment_grading: I think grading is acceptable but the guidelines is a bit blurry and subjective.
reviews.comment_workload: No exams just two papers and in-class negotiations. very light workload. Just remember to do all preparation work before the negotiation time. Preparations included read all the materials, jot down your notes on the way you would negotiate with others, what tactics you would like to use wtc.

reviews.author: nononope
reviews.title: Truly demonstrates the World Class in Asia at HKUST
reviews.comment_content: Covers all range of topics in everything there is about negotiation - truly an amazing learning experience, you can take this stuff with you in every aspect of life and these are life long skills you will never regret. Best part was all the actual negotiation cases we got to do on almost every single week. One of my top 5 courses here at UST.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Brad is an amazing guy, same goes for his TA ,Ginnie. They did an exceptional job on teaching the content, they were there till the end to answer all our questions and overall very helpful in general, nothing bad to say about them.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Class Participation: 25%
2. Attendance: 15%
3. Negotiation Preparation: 5%
4. Research Participation: 5%
5. Midterm Actual Negotiation: 20%
6. Final Actual Negotiation: 30%

Grading was pretty fair tbh, you can't really miss any classes thats one thing about it - since its a discussion and negotiation course, it's really important you show up to every class.

For the effort i put in i think i'm gonna get B+ to A - others did put more effort and some did get 100% on their midterms, so its definitely doable.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was minimal considering this is a 4 credit course - there were weekly readings which could take between 3-5 hours, and it was interesting stuff so didn't feel like work, also because i like reading.

Some cases needed not so much prep beforehand, but some cases needed some readings to do first, max i have spent here was again like 1 hour prepping for a case.

The midterm and final papers were interesting, you had to analyze and write about a negotiation experience and it was at 900 and 1800 words respectively. This needs a bit more creativity and thinking to do, took me 2 days for it each.

reviews.author: Amin Hachich
reviews.comment_content: super interesting, talks about negociation but even about psychology and how we should deal with complicated situation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
fluent english, good slides, always here to answer to the questions

We spend half of our time negociation which makes it a great experimental course
reviews.comment_grading:
talking about 2 negociations that we had to do, analyzing them with the class materials and write about them

All the rest is just participation and attendance
reviews.comment_workload: very light, sometimes we have to prepare a negociation case at home, it takes 20 min maximum and it's really nice

reviews.author: ieeliee
reviews.title: Make sure the prof likes you if you want a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
The content is fun. There are 2 session per week. One is the theory another is the negotiation. But there is no slides to review before lecture. So it may be hard to follow sometimes.

And sometimes, it is quite chill as we just watch negotiation video.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lessons are quite interesting and you can know some friends in the negotiation.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% first paper
25% second paper
25% participation

For the papers, there are no clear guidelines you can refer to and everything. Also, apart from "good", "bad" or the marks, there is no constructive comments that can really help you improve.

For participation, although it takes up a large part of the course grade, he usually just picked the students he likes to answer his questions. So, there is no way you can earn a good grade if you dont have "outstanding results" in the negotiation or brave enough to shout out the answers or ask questions.

Plus, there are so many international students in the class so the participation is quite vigorous.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is kinda light for a 4 credit course. It is just the preparation of negotiation and 2 1500 words papers. But it also means that you dont have much control of your grade since the large part is participation :)

reviews.author: Kyle CHEUNG
reviews.title: booster for you gpa
reviews.comment_content: have interesting paired-up or group practices and debriefs every week, which used for attendance record. the content is quite useful for your daily negotiation.
reviews.comment_teaching: quick reply on email and questions are always welcome. If you actively ask question, he will give you some tips for exam essay.
reviews.comment_grading: easy to get a good grade for adequate attendance, likely 100%. Use more in-class concepts in your essay and you will get a very high mark.
reviews.comment_workload: no heavy workload. sometimes require students to study the case background information before practice and may have very easy quiz, which can be answered by common sense, before class.

reviews.author: sillycantaloupe
reviews.title: Great course to take
reviews.comment_content:
Basic introductory course to negotiation, which is really interesting if you are into a lot of participation and talking.
There is a negotiation you have to partake in every course with a random partner, the results of the negotiation does not matter, but the results becomes tallied and then everyone has to discuss their behaviour and tendency during the negotiation.
This course is especially fascinating if you want to increase your awareness in communicating with others.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof is very engaging and patiently waits for everyone to talk and always responds in a very kind manner.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easy grading I think.
Prof grades in x/12, which is the curve.
reviews.comment_workload:
Super easy, two essays, 800 and 1600 words each.
Also participate?

reviews.author: Nick1234
reviews.title: Great content but poor grading
reviews.comment_content: There will be negotiation exercises every week for students to apply the concept learnt in class. I personally enjoyed the exercise very much as it is a very eye-opener experience to negotiate with different people every single week. There is a huge variety in the negotiation cases and each requires different negotiation styles and knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Stephen is a fun professor. He quoted a lot of real-life examples in classes and generally the classes are very interactive. You are free to voice out your opinion in class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not transparent. No constructive feedback is given for each assignment. Participation takes up a huge chunk of the grade, so it is important to attend the classes. Adequate time is given to complete each assignment.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light for 4 credit courses. There are only three assignments throughout the semester. There are no exams. However, you are expected to attend every class to earn participation scores. The assignments are on a real-life negotiation and the final assignment is related to negotiation analysis based on international events or movies.

reviews.author: skrskrskr
reviews.title: Negotiate wisely in life
reviews.comment_content: Funny negotiation cases each week, then debrief of the cases. You will learn a lot of practical skills to apply in different negotiations, such as in salary negotiation don’t mess up with the boss since relationship is important. The first essay requires you to negotiate in real life and write about it, I did step out of the comfort zone and negotiated with a restaurant, it was an unforgettable experience. To conclude, the course may teach you to try negotiating in any circumstance for the best outcome.
reviews.comment_teaching: One of the best professors in UST, Stephen encourages students to speak up, his presentation skills is good enough to make you pay attention to the class. Make sure be serious to the course since every second would also be an opportunity to acquire exciting knowledge, you never know when he is going to deliver helpful message, I was surprised in every debrief of the cases.
reviews.comment_grading: To me, very good grading. There are two negotiation essays which I both got A-, I believe it’s the participation brought me to an A at last. The key of the negotiation essays are the concepts of the class, include and expand on them would receive a high grade. Some people said that the grading is bad, it’s true that the course doesn’t have a high transparency, but you cannot expect participation mark to have high transparency, it’s intangible. 15% attendance for the negotiation exercises and 25% for the participation, make sure to answer more questions, it’s important to leave a good impression and also makes you to focus more in the class.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fine, you need to read a long passage to prepare for the negotiation each week. In the beginning, you need to read it during class. However, starting from like second week or third week, the passage is long and you need to read before the class. Remember to read the case thoroughly because this let you fully engaged and participate in the negotiation, you gonna learn and enjoy from it. There are quizzes with 2 MCs before the negotiation begins, just to test whether you have read the case or not, it’s not difficult but I remembered I got one mistake in the first quiz (marks were not disclosed but I just remembered). Hard work will pay off in this course, overall I paid great amount of effort in it so I am very satisfied with the grade.

reviews.author: Aaron W
reviews.title: Very fun and useful course
reviews.comment_content: The course covers a wide range of negotiation concepts, which are all very useful and practical. I won’t go into too much detail, since I think it’s best to go into the course blind.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Every week, during the first lesson we had a negotiation exercise, where we each have a secret role/objective, and then we negotiation with other students in the class. Then, during the second lesson, we see everyone’s results from the exercise and discuss, with the professor introducing the concepts that are relevant to the case.

Prof. Nason is a very fun professor and his classes were quite interesting. He often gives anecdotes from his own life and was very laid back, which made the whole experience quite approachable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Due to COVID, we had two term papers instead of exams. For the first one, we had to plan and execute a negotiation (could be anything) and write a paper analysing it using class concepts. For the second one, we had to analyze a negotiation of our own choice (in history or in a movie).

Grading:
Personal Negotiation: 20%
Negotiation Case Analysis: 25%
Negotiation Guide: 5%
Research Participation: 5%
Participation & Discussion: 25%
Attendance: 15%

Me:
Personal Negotaiton Case: B+
Negotiation Case Analysis: A
Attendance, Research Participation, Negotiation Guide: Full
Participation & Discussion: Unknown
Final Grade: A

Although he didn’t release the grading criteria until after the personal negotiation was due (would’ve been helpful if he gave it before), he did tell us how he graded the papers:
C range - wrong/very little use of class concepts
B range - correct/good use of class concepts
A range - going beyond class concepts or analysing the class concepts in further depth (e.g. counterintuitive findings)

As such, I think the grading was quite transparent and fair. For example, for my personal negotiation case, I didn’t use anything that went beyond the class concepts or analyze in that much depth, so a B+ is understandable. The case analysis was graded similarly, so I made sure to go beyond the class concepts for the second paper. Overall, I think he was quite generous with the grading, as I wasn’t expecting to get an A because my first paper was only a B+.

In my opinion, even if it was bad grading (which I don’t really think it is), this course is an easy recommendation, since it’s both fun and useful. The topics and concepts you learn are quite relevant to any negotiation and it was easily the most fun course I’ve taken in a while.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload wasn’t that much besides the preparation for the negotiation exercises, which mostly just required us to read our role and case information (~7 pages). The reports have a word limit (1000 for the personal case and 2400 for the case analysis) and you have a couple of weeks to do each.

One thing to note is that you should only register for this course if you are willing to participate in the negotiation exercises. Since these exercises are a major part of the course experience, not putting in the effort is both a waste of your own time, and it also ruins the experience for others.

In one of the exercises, we had a team negotiation where we each had separate information, but there was one girl on our team that was muted with her camera off and barely responded to anything we asked. This ruined the experience (as it’s like talking to a brick wall), and we only learned that she had crucial information we didn’t have when the other team asked us about it.

However, if you are willing to participate (which is quite easy since the cases are interesting and fun), it is definitely a worthwhile experience.

reviews.author: fluffy
reviews.title: Jeez probably the worst prof.
reviews.comment_content: Tbh, I'd say most of the content is pretty useful and practical.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not a fan of his teaching style, too much useless talking.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolutely shit, most ppl in the class got C range for the first essay which he didn't even give a clear instruction and grading rubric for it. Neither the second essay. Besides, participation takes a huge part of it but he only picks the students he likes (I personally think).

Final Grade: B
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of reading materials are required, one case study and one actual negotiation every week.

reviews.author: Peter yim
reviews.title: Very Fun Class, Must Reg Course in UST
reviews.comment_content:
Real Business case study and negotiation practice every week, one lesson for hands-on negotiation and the other for evaluation. content is very interesting and related to business.

Slides and its concepts are not too hard, very easy to understand, the weekly negotiation usually helps in understanding the slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nason is the best instructor, funny and inspiring, people in the class are very interactive because of the negotiation activities, there is a weekly negotiation result review and you can compare your skills with others.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite Nice already, as long as you attend lessons as part of the grade will be from a random negotiation result done in class.

Final is not too hard if you study well, overall difficulty is not too high.

Full attendance (as I enjoy the lesson quite a lot) plus above mean in midterm and final(maybe)?
Final Result: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Very Light, almost no assignment except you have to prep for next week's negotiation. Even you don't prep for it, it is also ok. But you may lose a chance to enjoy the fun of negotiating (chatting) with others.

Almost forgot there is some quiz in class but its so easy that you can do it without studying.

reviews.author: Chanhiuwing
reviews.comment_content: The content is mainly about different negotiation strategy and how to apply it in daily life which is quite funny.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is very funny. The course is not just about teaching the theory but there were negotiation practices every week that can help students have more understanding on what we learn and we can have fun during the practice.
reviews.comment_grading: The exam is quite challenging as you can not only memorise the theory but the most important is that you have to understanding! Understanding is the main point of having good grade on exam as many of the exam questions focused on application instead of memorisation.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is quite little. As there were only two exam, one midterm and one final. And yet there were some simple quiz but it was just very easy if you study the case study well.

reviews.author: kneberg
reviews.comment_content:
Content is fun -- every tuesday is a practice negotiation and every thursday is a discussion. This makes the lass very interactive and works well for lawyers who prefer to learn by doing!!

I have actually found the negotiation tactics in this class very useful already, which I didn't know if I would.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nason is a very enthusiastic teacher in negotiations. I have taken other classes taught by him, and this is definitely his best class to teach.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is very fair -- only one midterm and one final. There are super easy quizzes most weeks about the negiation case, easy to ace if you read the case. Just be on time!
reviews.comment_workload: Not hard at all.

reviews.author: Joshlam
reviews.title: A fun and useful course!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
The content is fun and useful.

Every week first lesson starts with a mock negotiation and the next lesson will be revealing the results and discussion about the concepts. Also, it comes with personal stories and real life example of negotiations to help you to be a better negotiator.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Nason is a exceptional professor, as his teaching is captivating and you always want to listen to what he was teaching.

He is also humorous and interactive, and you will learn something through the jokes and laughs.

Moreover, the teaching is not only about powerPoint as he will also share personal or real life examples of those negotiations which you will definitely like to hear.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is great.

But as this is a 4-credit course, the grading of the course becomes relative more important than other courses.

I am not really doing well in negotiations overall (one out of all negotiations results will be graded).

I am only at the mean for midterm and slightly above in the final.

And I got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's a two-question quiz for most negotiations and it will be quizzed before the mock negotiation. If you read the case which are distributed the class before, you will certain get a full mark.

Also, the preparation is important. Apart from reading the case, thinking about what tactics you will be using in the class in also important, this can help you get the best out of your negotiation result (better grades).

reviews.author: YEEEboi
reviews.title: Practical but gets a bit redundant starting mid-semester
reviews.comment_content:
Each week starts with a mock negotiation and then a review and discussion of results in the next class. The course involves quite sufficient practical skills and theories within negotiations and can be applied in multiple scenarios.

I personally recommend this course regardless of what school you study in. Do note that the course gets a bit dull after mid-semester as the concepts become quite repetitive.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nason's teaching style is really interactive and passionate. I believe most students enjoyed his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 30%
Final 30%
Neg results & guide 5%
Quizzes 5%
Participation and discussion 15%
Attendance 15%

I'd say the grading for this course is quite subjective since participation and discussion accounts for 15% of grading. However, having that in mind, your grades should be good as long as you participate in class and score 1 sd above for exams.

exams are tough btw.
reviews.comment_workload: Super light workload, just remember to read the negotiation cases before class.

reviews.author: strawberry cake
reviews.title: Interesting Course
reviews.comment_content: An in class negotiation exercise every week, and the other lesson was used as a review and going through the lecture slides. The content is very interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Funny and friendly professor.
reviews.comment_grading: I got a B+ for the course while I got the mean score in both the midterm and in the final exam. I achieved 100% attendance and have answered some questions in class for class participation. The exam is composed of both MC questions and a case study in which clear concepts towards the course materials is essential.
reviews.comment_workload: You are expected to read the case study (2-4 pages long) before each negotiation exercise.

reviews.author: JKJKJK
reviews.title: Best course
reviews.comment_content:
Very interesting and useful for life, you will not get bored during the course.
Esepecially the practice negotiations are great for learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very enthusiastic professor, he seems he is really into the teaching and enjoys the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair and with a good approach to the grading, not impossible to have a good grade with fair amount of studying.
reviews.comment_workload: Read cases, be ready and mindful during the lectures. You need to be able to cooperate with other students in the class , therefore you need to be prepared not to let them down

reviews.author: Julian_HK
reviews.comment_content:
Not much content, professor get simple key messages across.
It is sometimes depressing not to have learnt anything after 80 minutes of class beyond one single sentence.
reviews.comment_teaching: Enjoyable to listen to lecturer. Room conditions unfavourable.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading appears somewhat intransparent with regard to the participation component, as students never have name tags and very few questions are asked. This might be cause for concern. Generally, however, I have heard that grading would be rather fair, while skewed to participation.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload appears to be a appropriate for a course that provides 4 credits.

reviews.author: hnc
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content: A negotiation practice weekly. The content is interesting and useful. Knowledge learnt can be applied for daily usage.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nason is a very nice prof. He's teaching is fun and interesting. Materials and cases used are meaningful too.
reviews.comment_grading: I was a few marks below mean for midterm and 0.5 SD above mean for final. Skipped one negotiation practice in class. And got B at last. The grading is reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is okay. Have to read a case weekly to prepare for the negotiation practice. There will be a very short quiz to test on your understandings on the case.
One midterm and one final exam. Exams are not difficult. With MC and case studies. As long as u go through all the ppt and materials, that will be fine.

reviews.author: DontSearchMe
reviews.title: Interesting but...
reviews.comment_content: The content is all about negotiation and the skills. Each Tuesday you will have to nego with others, and will review the result in front of whole class on Thursday. You learn from your experience and jot your notes. His ppt is kind of trash, they are used for Prof Nason's teaching but not revision.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is interesting!
But the professor sitting in the class i.e. Daniel to teach in the next sem is quite boring(he taught for one class)
reviews.comment_grading: My grade is bad. Perhaps I am really not a good negotiator. I dont think it is easy to get good grade as you have to provide your views and opinions in the midterm and final for the given nego cases.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is to prepare and read the case before Tue class, or you will fail to negotiate with your classmate right away. And you may need to adjust your mindset to care less about the negotiation result if you are a poor negotiator like me

reviews.author: Ernest II
reviews.comment_content: The class is likely one of the most important classes you'll ever take in university. Teaches you a lot about negotiating and business behavior.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Nason is highly interactive and well-versed in Negotations. The class is interactive and requires you to throw out all self-reservations about engaging in class discussion. It will be you against another classmate once a week. It is war.
reviews.comment_grading: Nason is a tough, but fair grader. He'll give you about just as much as you put in. Stand up character.
reviews.comment_workload: You better show up for the weekly negotiation.

reviews.author: katiemaa
reviews.comment_content: You can learn a lot from Stephen, as he is really good at negotiation. The negotiation skills, principles, some theories will be taught. In most of the lessons, he will distribute cases for you to read one week before, then you need to do negotiation with one or more classmates, and afterwards you need to fill in the result sheet, this sheet marks as your participation mark and your negotiation mark, sometimes if you get a great deal, then your negotiation mark will be high for this exercise.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is funny and interesting, probably the most relaxing lesson in the semester, and he will share lots of interning stories with you. And most of the time will be put in the negotiation with classmates, and he will teach back the case and skills the lesson after.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good, if you didn't miss any negotiation, and do okay in the negotiation and have two exams above 0.5-1 SD, probably can get a range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just need to read cases one week before the negotiation lesson, and he will give a mini quiz about the case, but just very simple and easy, then you just negotiate with classmates.
Two exams in total, and just study the notes is fine.
No project and assignments!!!

reviews.author: olle
reviews.title: fun course but tough exams with harsh grading criteria
reviews.comment_content:
useful and practical content. talks about useful skill to be adopted in different types of negotiation (salary negotiation, cross-cultural negotiation, dispute, and so on)
The cases are really interesting and help you be involved in content because you actually have to fight for your side to get better results.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think he is the only professor that makes me get excited for my class. I always waited for Tuesdays and Thursdays just to hear him make fun of students with strange negotiation results. He also has many experiences and useful skills that he shares with students.
His lecturers make the time fly by and his slides are organized (but often really repetitive)
reviews.comment_grading:
35 % midterm
35% finals
30 % participation

Even though I participated a lot in class and did not miss a single class, I got a B because of my midterm and final grades. He has really tough grading criteria for his exams (like if you miss a specific word in your explanation, you will get your marks off)
69 out of 100 for midterm (exact average)
71 out of 100 for final (exact average)
participated a lot in class.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only a one or two page long case to be read every week. Do read and attend class because you actually need to negotiate with your partner(s) every week and this counts toward your final grade a lot.
Exams are the frustrating parts because the content is so easy to understand and vague that you never know how to prepare for the exams. Reading textbook does not seem to help that much (The book has too much content to be read)

reviews.author: student123
reviews.title: Highly recommend taking Negotiation
reviews.comment_content: The content was interesting and useful. I am sure I will apply some of the things, which I have learned, when negotiating in the future.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Nason was very engaging. His classes were never boring and his lectures were very straightforward.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading wasn't harsh at all. If you do your readings you will be fine. Make sure you understand all the concepts before exams tough because some of the questions are tricky.
reviews.comment_workload: You have to read a case before each lecture and prepare for the exams. There isn't too much work.

reviews.author: hwywy
reviews.comment_content: This course focuses on the techniques for different types of negotiation, like disputes and salary negotiation. There is one negotiation exercise every week, in which you can build up your negotiation skills and apply what you have learned in the lessons.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Nason's teaching is lively and interactive! He always tells us some interesting stories when he is illustrating the negotiation techniques. He loves to interact with students and it definitely brings up the teaching atmosphere.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is really good. I got an A for this course, even thoguh my mid-term and final exam results were above mean by around 0.5 sd only.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light for this course. You just have to read the assigned case every week and participate in the negotiation exercise. Besides one mid-term exam and one final exam, there is only one assignment due in the end of the course. The assignment is easy indeed- an A4 size personal negotiation guide.

reviews.author: r-money
reviews.title: best course at UST
reviews.comment_content: This course gives you great information about different negotiation strategies in the business world. It includes many different strategies and different techniques in order to gain the upper hand in business deals. It also teaches you to create scenarios that benefit both parties and can be used in all different aspects of life. I fundamentally enjoyed the content as a majority of it was non-theoretical and very practical. There are a lot of in class negotiations which i feel really highlighted the concepts. This course offers an opportunity to really interact with peers in class which is something that i really found lacking in HKUST.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Nason is one of the aspects that makes this course as incredible as it is. He was always very helpful and used different mediums of teaching which is perfect for both visual, practical and theoretical learners alike. He is a very open teacher and is more than happy to help out with concepts that may not be clear. He is a great teacher and has really made this course incredible.
reviews.comment_grading: In terms of grading, this course was fairly easy for me. I really enjoyed the teaching style and the different negotiation methods taught which probably contributed to the A i received. As long as you understand the concepts and have had practice applying them (which you should have if you attend the classes) you should be completely fine in both the final and the midterm exam. The final exams focus more on situations and how to adapt the negotiation styles to them. It is important to attend classes as well because the in class negotiation results are recorded and will be leveraged into your final grade through some percentage.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this course was very low. After each class, you receive a scenario for the next class which you should read up on and study (however they are usually 1-2 pages long so it isnt much reading to get through). I had a lot of time to focus on other courses during the semester and found that the majority of the learning was in class.

reviews.author: Vicvictse
reviews.comment_content: The content is very useful. It involves lots of real life examples and negotiation skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Professor is very friendly, knowledgeable and funny. Interactive learning and case studies are used. Active participation is encouraged. Do expect to speak a lot in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Grades are mainly determined by two exams and class participation.There are also quizzes on the weekly case assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: Preparation is a must. Everyone needs to read one case assignment every week. Only two exams and weekly negotiations on different case studies. No projects or written assignments.

reviews.author: Morris
reviews.title: A Great Course
reviews.comment_content: The content is base on the book "The Mind and Heart of the Negotiator". Each week there will be two class, one for negotiation of a case with an assigned role and the other class for debriefing for the last negotiation. You will be able to have a lot of hands on experience on negotiating a lot of different things in many different format.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Nason has been teaching in UST for over 20 years, and he is excellent in story telling. The class is usually engaging and thought provoking.

He will also include lots of stories from his personal experience to illustrate the theories mentioned in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading are mainly determined by mid term and final exam, which consist of MC questions and short case for the short question part.

There are also some quiz regarding to the case distributed.

Class participation marks are also one of the grading criteria.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week there will be a case distributed, and you will need to prepare it for the quiz and the negotiation itself. It will be a choice to prepare more or less, depends on your personal will. The bottom line is the more preparation you did, the better chance you have in succeeding the negotiations.

reviews.author: ThePostman
reviews.comment_content: This course is quite a fun one to take. On a weekly basis, you get a new case to then negotiate when coming back to class for an entire hour. The other class is spent discussing on the case and seeing how everyone could have done better.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor for this course is a really great one. I was looking forward to that course every week.
reviews.comment_workload: Little workload for this course. Probably one or two hours a week if it isn't to study for mid-terms or finals.

reviews.author: Alfred Ho
reviews.title: One of the best course I have ever taken as a engineering student
reviews.comment_content:
There are two lectures every week with one being a negotiation practice and the following one be the breakdown of the negotiation results.

There is also two papers that have to submit for midterm and final. Both of them are analysing a negotiation. One is a new negotiation conducted by yourself and you have to analyse it with what have been taught in class. The other one is to analyse a historical one.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Nason is one of the professor I have met in UST. As a engineering student, I have never seen such a humorous and energetic prof like him. His sharing of different negotiation cases and his own experience always make the class fun and energetic.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is good
reviews.comment_workload: workload is not that much as a 4 credit course. However, attendance is extremely important as the negotiation is held during the class.

reviews.author: igil
reviews.title: First impressions
reviews.comment_content: The class is about improving the student's negotiation skills and focusses on practical negotiation exercises through case studies.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor seems fantastatic! Young, dynamic and knowledgeable. But it is worthwhile to note that he is also rather strict when it comes to attending class and being on time.
reviews.comment_grading: I did not have the exams yet...
reviews.comment_workload: The workload seems quite light, especially for a four credits class. You just have to read a few pages of the book per week, but other than that, class requires very little preparation.
